brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides a rule that checks for the presence of @Converter annotation on JPA converter.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'JPA_Converter_Annotation_Check' checks all classes in the project. If the class name ends with 'Converter', it asserts that the class should be annotated with '@Converter'. If the class is not annotated with '@Converter', it generates a message indicating that the class is a JPA converter but is not annotated with '@Converter'.
new_built-in_functions_explanation if an: The built-in functions used in this rule are 'getClasses', 'getName', 'endsWith', 'hasAnnotation', and 'getFQN'. No new functions were introduced.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/jpa-attribute-converters
Summary: This page explains how to use JPA Attribute Converter to map a custom model's attribute to a database column. It emphasizes the importance of annotating the converter class with @Converter.

2. URL: https://thorben-janssen.com/jpa-21-how-to-implement-a-custom-basic-type-using-attribute-converter/
Summary: This page provides a detailed guide on how to implement a custom basic type using Attribute Converter in JPA 2.1. It also highlights the necessity of using the @Converter annotation.
